title: Teach me how to get out of Bronze
body:
First off, this isn't a rant about how shit my team mates are, after talking to a couple of friends in high elo(one just got into diamond the other day, the other has been diamond since probably before I even started playing), I've picked up that shitty team mates and afks and trolls are everywhere, not just in bronze.

I want to know how to get good enough to carry 4 sacks of potatoes consistently, I watch streams, my own replays, I read up guides on 'cheese' strategies and how they work, what they do etc, but I feel like I've hit a brick wall.

halp pls

replies.body:
The main thing to accept is that if you feel like your team mates are shit, then you're very likely playing just as badly as them and you haven't even noticed. After all, you're the same rank as them.

So how do you get out of Bronze? Simple. This is going to sound insulting, but keep in mind that I was the bottom of Bronze too when I started the game. How do you get out of Bronze (or Silver for that matter)? By learning the basics of the game.

You will feel like you have a good grasp on the game now, but you certainly don't. Or else you'd be Gold or high Silver. Go back to basics. Practice CSing in customs. Study the rules of trading. Focus harder on preventing deaths. Learn good ward placement. Consider which items to build situationally rather than following a cookie-cutter build (e.g. build armor to counter physical dmg, build MR to counter magic dmg). Start watching the map. Make plays on objectives at the right times (when you have a numbers advantage due to jungle ganking the other side of the map, for instance).

These things sound simple, but no Bronze player does more than 1 or 2 of them to any level of competency. If they did, they'd be high Silver minimum.
Thanks, good and solid advice, I didn't even know there were rules for trading, will look them up now.

I laughed.

Cause this is a waste of gold in bronze, no bronzie looks at the map.

Maybe they dont look at the minimap very often. And maybe they dont respond to retreat pings when you warn them of an impending gank. But even the worst players will usually notice if the enemy is walking over wards AND you're pinging it.

I have played in bronze, and sure SOME people look at the map, and look at the map when you ping, but most don't.

Honestly your better off not wasting the gold and actually just keeping track of the enemy laners/jungler
if you think you can get the same info from just keeping track of the enemy jungler/laners, you're probably warding in the wrong places lol
If you think you can't you probably have no game knowledge.

Theres a big difference between say, " their blues coming up, the junglers probably bot side" and "Their blues coming up and their jungler just walked over to it on 25% hp". Its not just about avoiding ganks, the plays you can make with that extra knowledge can turn into a big advantage. If all you needed to do was have an idea of where people were, challenger/lcs players would never need to buy wards at all.

Considering in Bronze nearly everyone is stupid enough to back in vision (including junglers) you can actually gather from map info if they are going to blue on 25% hp.

Also saying that LCS players don't need wards because Bronzie's don't need wards is crap, LCS players will use the vision, and still have the game knowledge to know where the jungler is even without them, plus they ward for different reasons then bronzie's need to anyway.

Sure you can get info and do stuff without wards. But that doesn't mean you can't get MORE info and make more plays with them. I could go play in bronze and get a decent winrate without buying a singal ward, but I could do even better if I was warding too, even if not one of my teammates was looking at the minimap.
Well as a support you tell your adc to move when you see them coming to gank or when to engage or disengage if they are "blind"

Getting better at any team game with a bad team relies on adaptation rather than pure skill in almost any situation. Try being nice and asking what your team mates prefer, sometimes different preferences in tactics and strategies are what cause others to seem bad at the game. Or, try to check if your team mates are willing to listen to what you prefer.

My most successful laning phases as a mid laner are the ones where either I or the jungler say something about who should engage first, or how far the lane has to be pushed before a gank.

That's a very good point, however, I've seen firsthand people hard carry games that seem to be unwinnable with pure skill. (i think?)

To me, this seems to be the most consistent way to win games, just by being really good at the game that it's hard for you to lose.

hard carrying is actually a unique type of adaptation, you hide behind everyone else in a team fight and get kills until you can 1v1 anyone if you're squishy, or simply get a lot of kills and not follow your team around as you're powerful enough to do what you think is needed and let the other 4 guys do the rest.

I always do that when I have less faith than usual in my team. I hide behind the support, avoid using my abilities on people with more than half health, and continue doing this until I get enough kills to solo their tank, dragon, or 2v1. But so far I've only managed to do so with Veigar bot carry.
I never thought of it like that, I always thought it was like just one guy outplaying a whole team lol haha

Lol you'll very rarely win 1v1 consistently at even skill due to the matchmaking system. People in bronze make a LOT of mistakes, in every game, and you can snowball a huge lead by simply capitalising on these mistakes. Rather than trying to constantly make big plays and risk messing up/dying to a gank/having your team not follow up, look for opportunities where the enemies mess up (taking a bad trade, chasing too far, facechecking stuff alone, staying in lane/going back to jungle with super low hp) and exploit these. And remember your teammates are also bronze and adjust you're play accordingly. A play that might might be good when you see a challenger player doing it on stream might not be good if your teammates might take 5 seconds to notice when you engage or are likely to mess up their combo.

The thing to remember, is that if everyone in bronze has the mental agility of a potato. Then if you were to focus on last hitting, mechanics, positioning. Your team will have 4 potatoes vs their 5 potatoes. Easy win.
